meetings/cloudkitty-team-meeting.yaml.message: I think this is actually making it less clear. I would keep it as it was before. Or, if you actually intend to make this even weeks which your ML post made it sound like, change the frequency above and change "first and third" to "second and fourth"?
Ah, I guess it depends if you are counting even and odd based by year or by month. As it is today, it appears to be by month, so the first and third Mondays would be the two odd weeks.

As stated on the mailing list:

Unless I am mistaken, a schedule based on the Nth day of month is not fixed to even or odd weeks.
For example, in June the first and third Monday were in weeks 23 and 25 (odd), but since July they take place in even weeks.

What I am proposing is we disregard the existing description and go by the frequency defined in the yaml file, which is biweekly-odd.

It means that people who have already imported the calendar invite will have the correct date (although not the right description).

And we'll always have two weeks between each meeting, instead of sometimes three.
So maybe append "... of the year" to make this more clear. Could also state "See iCal link for specific dates."

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_dri.message:
Good catch.

A couple of things.

1) https://github.com/ovn-org/ovn/blob/1e07781310d8155997672bdce01a2ff4f5a93e83/ovn-nb.ovsschema#L85-L89

This parameter is an integer, not a list


2) IMO, the command should not change the object values. That should be done properly in the methods calling this one. When creating the port object, getting the port options: https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/ccbebfeaccf657caf8bcf8d635e3032e4c51c658/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/ovn_client.py#L233


When a port can have a tag=None?
TY Terry! I do not think I can add to what you said. <3

Well, in this case of course this change makes sense. We don't need to take care of "tag" outside this method, we'll handle the None/unset status here.

Thanks for the clarification.

About the ovs code, I didn't know the unspecified value was defined as an empty list. But as you said, this is in python-ovs, we won't change that here.

Good to learn!

1) It is an *optional* integer (min:0, max:1), which is implemented in ovsdb as a set containing 0 or 1 items. It's weird. I hate it. :p

2) This is basically doing what the underlying python-ovs code does: set an "unspecified" valued to the default value, which for this type is an empty set (list, because of other things I hate about python-ovs). We could do something like:

 if 'tag' in self.columns and self.colums.get('tag') is None:
     del self.columns['tag']

but this will end up doing the same thing. As an example, the version of this command that is ovsdbapp (which we never got around to using) handles the case where tag=None: https://github.com/openstack/ovsdbapp/blob/master/ovsdbapp/schema/ovn_northbound/commands.py#L378 and this was pretty much a direct translation of how ovn-nbctl handles things: https://github.com/ovn-org/ovn/blob/master/utilities/ovn-nbctl.c#L1391 (with tag=-1 similar to tag=None/unspecified).

3) This I'm not sure of, but Flavio mentioned in our chat that this was happening with a localnet port, so it might be in that case.

glance/api/v2/images.py.message: Is this good enough? Two worker processes on the same host will have the same hostname yet they need to be excluded as well right?

Oh I see, you're checking separately for the case where we raced against ourselves. In that case, this doesn't abort if we raced against another worker, right? I get that the potential for corruption is worse in the single-node-race case, but in the multi-node case, you could cause glance to DDoS the rbd store, the network, etc. Seems like we need to fix both of those cases.
Yes, this will be handled at line #193
Shouldn't this be defined as a constant somewhere to avoid typos breaking the locking mechanism?

I think this is the same race condition.

1. worker1 gets the image with blank properties
2. worker2 gets the image with blank properties
3. worker1 "claims" the import by saving its hostname
4. worker2 "claims" by also saving its hostname, clobbering worker1
5. both workers are proceeding.
Yes, this approach does not eliminate the race condition fully, still need to think about this as well.
We need to do image = image_repo.get(image_id) after the image_repo.save(image) ... otherwise we're just comparing to the same object we just modified, not what's in the database.

That will help us rule out the competing node worker case, but we can't really know whether or not we were competing with another thread on the same host if we do that.

Doesn't a task have a uuid on creation, before it's started? Maybe using that as our test-and-set key would be more robust than hostname? I dunno if glance has any such requirements, but it's easy to have multiple machines that think their hostname is 'localhost' which breaks this kind of thing :)

That said, this surely feels to me like it is begging for something at the persistence layer to make sure we don't allow two images to go into a task state at the same time...

This will always be the empty string if we think we won the race, or another worker's host if we didn't, so it will never be equal to our hostname, AFAICT.

If you re-query the image from the database after your transaction is completed above, then you could compare the value in the image to your hostname and know that if it's different, you lost and abort.

However, I think the better thing to do would be to make the DB layer only agree to update the "locked by host" key if that key is currently not set, atomically in the same transaction as the update.

I was going to say, probably don't want to show this to the user, so this is good. However, maybe this key should be named something more specific to import or tasks?

Can someone set this property via PUT (i.e image update) if they know the magic? That seems like it would be bad, in case someone clobbers this value without realizing its importance.
this needs to be restricted in update, good catch.

This is just less likely to conflict, but it's not impossible. We have patterns to solve things like needing to generate unique identifiers, so why not use them?

The task being created below has a uuid, why not use it as the exclusion key?

https://github.com/openstack/glance/blob/master/glance/domain/__init__.py#L476

Yes, it means doing the check further down near where the task is created, but there are good reasons for that too. See below.

This only makes a race condition less likely to occur (and less likely to notice, debug, etc). Delaying isn't really a reasonable thing to do in an API worker, IMHO, nor really in any attempt to resolve a race. AFAIK, sleep() isn't monotonic, and is only guaranteed to be longer (wall clock time) than the value you provide. Running in a virtual machine where time can warp can make things like this not behave like you expect.
If you fail here, you will not release your lock on the image.
If you fail here you will not release your lock on the image.

Right here, you can claim the image with your unique identifier, otherwise fail and you won't have to worry about all the cleanup paths. You can use the unique ID of the task instead of less precise/random keys.

However, I still don't see how this is going to do anything other than reduce the likelihood of the race. Here's an execution sequence that will still let the race occur:

1. worker1 gets image, sees no lock
2. worker2 gets image, sees no lock
3. worker1 claims lock, sleeps
4. worker1 gets image, sees it has the lock
5. worker2 claims lock, sleeps
6. worker2 gets image, sees it has the lock
7. both workers are running, thinking they have the lock

High system load between steps 2 and 5 cause worker2 to be more delayed in between getting the image initially and writing its claim on the lock.

You really need something atomic here to prevent this. I haven't looked at your data structures, but you need something like this:

 UPDATE images SET images.os_glance_hidden_check=$me WHERE images.id==$image_id AND images.os_glance_hidden_check=NULL

We could ask Mike Bayer to help with this if you want.

Hey Mike,

You're offline on IRC right now so I'll try pinging you later to chat about this. But, we're looking for some help with an atomic operation whereby one of many threads of glance-api can kinda stake its claim on an image for a long-running operation. We need to be able to set that property on the image and know whether we "won" or "lost" so we know whether or not to continue or bail.

I think we probably want/need an atomic "create if not exists or fail" ImageProperty row, buried in Image.save() or as a separate operation. Wondering if you could help with the proper pattern here to do this effectively.
we could ask Mike, good to get more inputs.
Now we can avoid use of these functions as we can set any value to the property.
How about we just set the value to the request-id so that if we needed to we could correlate the job to logs, post-recovery? I also think that using the task id would be good.
This prevents an operator from clobbering the value I assume?
Yes, These are the properties which are reserved and not allowed to update by any user.
Random whitespace damage
Done
This isn't tested
simple way to test this is to mock the method and check whether it is called or not

Would it not be better to name this something that will be more meaningful and potentially useful for other things? What about something like os_glance_task_in_progress? Presumably we'd be well off to preclude other tasks from running on an image at the same time? Or maybe os_glance_import_task or something import-specific?
Done

Just to reiterate your logic here, this is saying that the client's process needs to be this:

 1. Make the request, if 202 then continue
 2. If the value is "Pending", then the task is waiting to get picked up, continue polling until timeout
 3. If the value is something other than pending (i.e. a uuid), then look to see if our store is in the copying_to_stores list
 3a. If it is, then keep polling
 3b. If it is not, then guess about whether or not our request has been queued behind the one for the other store, or if we should wait for that importing_to_stores key to be empty and then try again.

Since glance doesn't queue currently, the client will have to make it all the way through step 3b before deciding to wait and retry or give up. The way we had this code before, we could know all of this from the always-consistent return value in step 1.

 > intentionally).

This won't surprise anyone, but I have always been partial to the Tasks API.  I wonder whether instead of keeping it admin-only, we should make it read-only for non-admins.  Then we can keep the task_id as the lock content and return a 201 as Erno suggests.

Then we can move the locking back to the taskflow task, which would address Erno's earlier locality concerns--the lock/revert/release code can all be in one place.

When a task can't get the lock, it can go to 'failure' status and return a link to the blocking task in the message.  (And allowing a user to list tasks will solve that problem about expired tasks not being deleted--I don't think that bug was ever fixed.)

Tasks never had a DELETE method (they auto-expire) so we don't have to worry about that.  We will have to make sure that the 'input' element doesn't leak anything (I think it doesn't because all it contains is the info from the original request, though once the API became admin-only, we may not have been so careful when creating "internal" tasks).

Thus the Tasks API can function as a cross between the Cinder User Messages API and Nova faults.

We had lenghty chat with Abhishek about the timing and where these things should be done. I think there's three parts to it:
First of all we shouldn't be reverting stuff in the task that the task did not set. Doing so will very easily lead to more spagetti and unmaintainable code for anyone trying to understand later on what's going on here.
Second thing is, that if there is an issue where the taskflow doesn't actually start for some reason, we would be placing lock and never removing it as placing the lock happens outside of taskflow but removing it happens inside. We've seen examples of this before for example in the uwsgi case where taskflow thinks it has started correctly but the worker actually never comes up.
Third point is indeed the failing as early as possible that speaks for the otherwise more problematic behaviour. I would 100% agree to that being the most important factor should this call be something where operational success was actually tied to returning to the client. But as async nature of the import call, the client needs to be prepared that the processing might fail for some reason. If this reason is very unlucky timing of the calls (we're still talking about very simultaneous requests if they are not caught in the check at API) that is one part of it.

Like always, migitations like this are compromise and I think processing the locking both ways in the same process is the better compromise long term.

Having just written a client to consume this and then trying to figure out what's going on, I can say it's not great to have to guess. In the original case where glance wasn't configured to run standalone, and the task never got started, my code would wait for the looong timeout before giving up, because it didn't know that the task hadn't even started. By moving this check to async, that same thing can/will happen, even if glance *is* properly configured which means the consuming code has to have two timeouts and more complex state logic. It has to have a short timeout to see that the requested store has at least shown up in "importing_to_stores" and then once that is satisfied, go into a longer wait for it to go into "stores" or "import_failed". Those really need to be tunable, which means nova has to have more config to support this.

Right now, the get_flow() function below sets the state of the image to "importing" which is a (non-atomic) image lock in a very similar way. That will run before the API call returns and would fail if something else raced with us to set that state, with good reason. Similarly, the task updates the state to "active" on completion (for non-copy import methods), even though it wasn't the task itself that set the status to "importing" in the first place. This seems like the same thing to me as this lock the same behavior and requirement, although it makes it truly atomic, which is why I think it should be set before the API returns.

Does doing it in the get_flow() function (instead of here so that it is synchronous with the API call) make it more integrated with the task to satisfy your concern about being tight coupling between the API and the task behavior?

The thing is, you have that case _regardless_ so you really have to have some way for the operator to fix it. If you're running one of these tasks and the power goes out, or the OOM killer nukes glance, or some overzealous container manager/fencing agent kill -9s everything, you're going to leave lock (and other, as we noted in a couple other bugs) residue that has to be cleaned up.

I think the way taskflow expects you to solve that is by using its persistence mechanism (although I'm far from a taskflow expert) so that the reverts can run after you come back and clean up the task repo. The way we tend to do this sort of thing in nova is that we scope things like that to a node that is doing them, and on service startup, we look for remnants of past unfinished tasks.

So, point being, please let's make the API consistent for the client, since we have to solve the out-of-band cleanup problem anyway. I previously brought up the post-disaster cleanup case on an earlier patch set and Abhi acknowledged that we'd need to have some mechanism for that anyway.

This changes the API behavior for other types of import operations. Right now, when the API returns 202, the image has already changed to importing. After this change, a quick re-poll may see the image as whatever the original state was and not importing, which may cause a polling loop to fail. It's already unfortunate that copy-image doesn't get an externally-visible indication that things are happening, so I wouldn't extend that to the rest of the methods :)

Right here, you open the race back up. You've removed the Pending and saved the image, which means another API thread has the opportunity to jump in here. You will fail on L307, but you've already reported to the API client of *this* thread that you're going to do what they asked. So if there's a race, the two threads can invert their positions...the first one that grabbed the lock will die and the later one that should have been kept out will succeed.

Will taskflow run the revert() of this step if execute() fails? If so, then you will delete the *other* thread's pending lock as you try to clean up your own.

One benefit of using the task ID as the value is that we *can* check to make sure we're reverting our own lock and not someone else's, but if everyone uses the same pending value we can't do that.

> Are you saying that the set_property_atomic is not atomic after all
 > and you can just overwrite it by calling it again?

No? You're not overwriting it, you're deleting it and then re-adding it. If you *update* the value in place, that is atomic. Deleting and setting it again opens a gap where it's unset. That's the situation I describe above, where the newer thread can jump in front of the old one.

 > I understood
 > that as long as that we go that route instead of the normal update
 > and save dance we never have collision like you described.

As I explained above, since you've deleted the value, only one of the old and new thread will succeed in calling the atomic set, but you can't be guaranteed that it will be *this* one. Since *this* one is the one that originally won the lock race, reported 202 to the client, we want to exclude other tasks from starting until this one finishes. If we instead swap places with another task,
we have to fail as we've lost our lock. If that happens continually, nothing makes progress.

 > Updating the pending here to task id I can see being problematic
 > due to the shortish self healing timeout of the pending soft lock
 > for the api layer (that's why release and atomic lock again), but I
 > do not see how two tasks would go beyond this point unless the
 > set_property_atomic is not atomic after all.

I didn't say "two tasks would go beyond this point", I said that this task will voluntarily drop its lock, and then fail to re-gain it on L307, because the other task grabbed it. We will fail, so two will not proceed, but you end up with a DoS potential, and you have lied to your client when you reported 202, indicating that the request would be acted upon.

"""10.2.3 202 Accepted

The request has been accepted for processing, but the processing has not been completed. The request might or might not eventually be acted upon, as it might be disallowed when processing actually takes place. There is no facility for re-sending a status code from an asynchronous operation such as this.

The 202 response is intentionally non-committal. Its purpose is to allow a server to accept a request for some other process (perhaps a batch-oriented process that is only run once per day) without requiring that the user agent's connection to the server persist until the process is completed. The entity returned with this response SHOULD include an indication of the request's current status and either a pointer to a status monitor or some estimate of when the user can expect the request to be fulfilled. """
- https://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html

Like mentioned before, with 202 we never made that promise. We just responded that "Your request has everything that needs to be there for success and we assume it will be processed eventually" The 202 is very clear not promising success, just indicating that the request is acceptable for processing.

I think this is where our understanding differs as you seem to think that because we accepted the request, there is desired result guaranteed, which is not the case and all this is being implemented to make the clients life easier. If you (as main stakeholder trying to implement the usecase for it) disagree with that being useful, we can just drop the indication and truly leave the guess work to the client side. But personally I do think that anything we can give to the client to indicate where we are at towards success or failure would be improving the user experience.

I'm open for the DoS potentian if you can show me an example how to exploit it. AFAIK being able to build exploit for this would require either very specific and predictable timing or non-ratelimited API and malicious already trusted user (as this is policy controlled for 3rd party already).

Are you saying that the set_property_atomic is not atomic after all and you can just overwrite it by calling it again? I understood that as long as that we go that route instead of the normal update and save dance we never have collision like you described.

Updating the pending here to task id I can see being problematic due to the shortish self healing timeout of the pending soft lock for the api layer (that's why release and atomic lock again), but I do not see how two tasks would go beyond this point unless the set_property_atomic is not atomic after all. 

Yes it will execute revert(), catch on lines 325-326 that we failed here and not delete it.

> Like mentioned before, with 202 we never made that promise. We just
 > responded that "Your request has everything that needs to be there
 > for success and we assume it will be processed eventually" The 202
 > is very clear not promising success, just indicating that the
 > request is acceptable for processing.

But we don't "have everything that needs to be there for success." One of the things required for success, which is implied given Glance doesn't have a serialization or queuing mechanism, is "you're the only one asking for an import operation on this image right now." If we put the request into a queue so it would be processed before or after all the other competing ones, then I'd totally agree with you :)

 > I think this is where our understanding differs as you seem to
 > think that because we accepted the request, there is desired result
 > guaranteed, which is not the case and all this is being implemented
 > to make the clients life easier. If you (as main stakeholder trying
 > to implement the usecase for it) disagree with that being useful,
 > we can just drop the indication and truly leave the guess work to
 > the client side. But personally I do think that anything we can
 > give to the client to indicate where we are at towards success or
 > failure would be improving the user experience.

I'm not sure how we could be providing *less* information to the client than we are. I'm assuming you're just saying that to indicate that I should be happy with what I've got and not complain -- not that you actually want to provide less info right? :)

I _am_ the stakeholder here, and AFAIK, I'm potentially the only one who has written a client-side cloudy use of this feature. Even being a developer, able to talk to the other developers, read and modify the code, etc, it's almost unusable as it is. All I'm trying to do is bring my experience _actually_ writing a client against this to help make it better.

 > I'm open for the DoS potentian if you can show me an example how to
 > exploit it. AFAIK being able to build exploit for this would
 > require either very specific and predictable timing or
 > non-ratelimited API and malicious already trusted user (as this is
 > policy controlled for 3rd party already).

As I said above, the DoS would be a constant state of priority inversion where I create new tasks at a rate such that I'm consistently jumping into this gap where you have dropped the lock and cause no tasks to make forward progress. If I can consistently cause new tasks to grab the lock while you drop it, then no task will ever make it past this point.

cinder/volume/drivers/dell_emc/powermax/.message: This is going to lead to some misleading logging.  When everything goes well, you'll log the message at line 3982 and then also log the message at line 3985.
True, will remove this finally clause and move this debug message to the outer where _cleanup_on_migrate_failure is initially called.

this doesn't use the

  except Exception as e:
       try:
           _call_cleanup_function()
       finally:
           raise e

pattern you've been using elsewhere.  Was there a reason for that?

That being said, I'm not sure either pattern does what you really want.  I take it the idea is that we want to raise the exception that occurred in the normal flow, not any other exception that arose during the cleanup (those methods are logging as they go).  The problem with both patterns is that if an exception happens in the cleanup function, it doesn't have a handler despite being inside a try block (there's no 'except' block).  So you're going to have one of those "During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred" situations.  I wonder if you want something more like this:

  except Exception as e:
      try:
           _call_cleanup_function()
      except Exception:
           # just catch it, we don't care, we logged it already
           pass
      finally:
           # reraise the original exception, keeping its original context
           raise
That works for me. Think about what makes the most sense and you can handle it in a followup patch.

I think the original idea was to display both exceptions in that way but in a real world scenario this would most likely just be redundant. I can update all of these similar calls to use the try except finally and write out any debug messages necessary if an exception occurs during _call_cleanup_function().

So then this would become ctlplane_address
And we would no longer need this line
Right, but the ctlplane would be set by SSHClient's __init__ on L42, and NSM can just have the service_host/host.

Downstream, the NSM still needs a way of holding both hostname and control plane address. If it only gets the control plane address it will not have any knowledge of the hostname it needs to use when accessing the compute service status and will fail to get the service information.  Passing the hostname to the NSM init and then doing the control plane IP lookup allows downstream to pass the control plane IP to the SSHClient while still using the hostname when accessing compute services.

  for more details.
It has two "_", I think you should remove one.
Thanks stephenfin, got it, IMO, it ok for one _ or two _ at here.

This was actually correct as it was. Two underscores means "don't create an anchor for this." With one underscore, it creates an anchor so you can reference it later in the document like so:

  blah blah blah `bug 1841932`_ blah.

which is okay in this case but should generally be avoided in release notes since anchors must have unique names and we could end up with conflicts on more generic names (e.g. "see `this bug <https://.../>`_ for more information").

I think we should be using sysfs instead of symlinks here... We could do something similar to what I did in method `_get_connection_devices`, which gathers the info from iscsiadm and uses sysfs directly to get the devices.

In this case we would just look for a specific target-portal-lun and ignore the rest.

What do you mean by the last sentence?  Couldn't I just change these 3 lines of code to:
devices = _get_connection_devices(None, ips_iqns_luns)?

You can, but then you are doing extra work, because you are not limiting the glob to just the luns...  But then again, it's probably best to reuse a method we already know works than write a new one for a small optimization.

So yes, you should just use _get_connection_devices.
Instead of splitting the string multiple times, it might be better to split it once up front and assign to a variable that can be used throughout.
OK, if this code still exists after Gorka's comment about using sysfs rather than symlinks I will do that.

Should we check the WWN if we have it and only remove it if it's different?

I have mixed feelings, because if it's the same device, we have buffered data that hadn't been written, and we haven't written data to this volume on any other host, we could prevent data loss by preserving the device.  On the other hand, if we have attached the volume on some other host and written data, we could be corrupting it...
I'm OK with that as long as we all agree.  It would be good to add a comment here to reflect that we've made this conscious decision.

I think it's safer to discard the data. Applications/File-systems will probably deal better with the last writes being discarded (as would happen with any disk that has a write cache), rather than taking the risk of the volume being used on another host and then corrupting it later on.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Not a minus one: When we started the API, we explicitly decided not to make any compatability guarantees.  It would be okay to go ahead and change both the front and backend right now.  I would be okay with that if you wanted to update the change for it.  However, that would make it difficult to test this change with the live dashboard jobs, so if you want to keep this as written, that's okay with me too.  But I think we should remove the compatability immediately afterwords.

If folks thing we now want to start maintaining multiple versions of the API indefinitely, then I think that needs a mailing list discussion.  However, I would object to that.  That seems an easy way to accumulate technical debt indefinitely and I think we have better things to do with our limited time.

If we don't make any compatibility guarantees, I'm fine to ditch this header field. I just came up with this in the first place because I thought you wanted to have the API compatible :D

Regarding the live dashboard test: This is - even if I keep it like this - only testable once the change is deployed to the zuul instances that serve as API for the live dashboard, or? Thus, even if we keep it like that, the follow-up change for the frontend https://review.opendev.org/#/c/746463/ cannot immediately be tested in the live dashboard.

So I'm fine with removing this part and I would rather not start a discussion about compatibility or not if you don't have a guarantee for it ;-)

nodepool/driver/gce/adapter.py.message: pep8: F841 local variable 'ram' is assigned to but never used
pep8: F841 local variable 'machine_type' is assigned to but never used

Looking at the old code in createInstance it appears that machine_type might be able to be deterministically generated without a network round drip. Should we do that here instead of caching and doing what I presume is a network lookup below?

The variable machine_type here is a URL of the same form as what was in createInstance.  That much is correct.  But what this method does is now return a MachineType REST object which has the extra information (such as number of CPUs for this machine) that we need to calculate quota.  We update createInstance to use the selfLink (ie URL) of this object instead of deterministically creating the URL for 2 reasons: it's potentially more resilient if they change the scheme in the future, and we're going to need this for the quota calcs anyway.  So yes, there is an extra network call (but only one -- it's cached) compared to before, but that extra call is needed for quota calcs regardless, so keeping the old behavior in createInstance won't reduce that.
I guess there is no ram limit?
That appears to be the case.  Lots of other limits, no RAM that I saw.  I thought it was weird too.

docs/source/virtual_redfish_bmc.md.message: The community felt we should name vendors in this document, so rather than specifying DELL, it should be x86 server with x86 CPU's, etc.

I'll keep these specifications in here, as a "this is what we tested it on" and suggest that it should work similarly for other linux versions as well as hardwares, that satisfy the similar minimum requirements.
I see. Okay, I'll patch it up.

Not sure we can always got a clean separation.
When we list operating system it is specific one with a version. It doe snot mean "generic" Linux.
Since we allow it we can do the same with HW.
It is expected to work with any HW and any OS. But it was tested on this specific configuration and OS version.

But I agree that we need to be precise what is expected and what was tested.
same thing here refer to vendor specific OS instructions. in other words keep the document generic.

here we do not need to be Dell specific.

Out of curiosity, why it is AMD image for Intel server?
It is VM so it does not really matter.
Unless it was deliberate to demonstrate Independence of baremetal OS and VM OS.

I agree it doesn't matter much.
AMD-64 as an instruction set is obviously different from the IA-64 instruction set. However, I believe the term amd64 used  here is loosely used to name a "64 bit architecture OS image", like its counterpart i386. It's the only downloadable option, that's why I have this hypothesis. We needn't worry.

I suppose this is sufficient time to account for the 50s increase here if most of the time was waiting for the bmc to respond.

Thank you for the review John.

This is not a 10s -> 50s inline wait.
Its simply a timeout increase from 10 to 50.
The power status is polled every second (+ the command handling time) and once the BMC returns the requested power state then the loop exits as a result of new state = desired state or (self.power_state == state).

neutron/templates/bin/_neutron-openvswit.message:
I don't quite get the logic here yet, why do we need to set other_config:update_config=true, then set it back to false below?    I thought if UPDATE_CONFIG is true, then we will just simply run the set of commands and if it is false, then don't do anything?

The logic now may work the first time, but if it restarts with UPDATE_CONFIG=false, it may still run the code again because ovs_update_config would be "empty"?  I could be wrong here.

Ok thanks for the explanation, I think I understand the logic better now.  I was just thinking maybe it would be easier if we simply check either if "UPDATE_CONFIG is true" or if "bridge/bond does not exist", then create/update it, otherwise skip over, but your logic may be better perhaps.

Either way, can we at least change the name from "UPDATE_CONFIG" to "UPDATE_DPDK_BOND_CONFIG", something to indicate the narrow application of this flag.

If we just use UPDATE_CONFIG as a flag we can either run the commands or not run them. But, in this case we need to run the commands for the first time and the next time run them at will.

With this logic, let's say UPDATE_CONFIG=false, for the first run ovs_update_config will be empty. Which means the below set of commands will run and then set other_config:update_config=false.

In case of a pod restart, UPDATE_CONFIG is still false, but ovs_update_config is set to false in the first run. So, the set of commands will not be run.

If UPDATE_CONFIG=true, then other_config:update_config=true, ovs_update_config will be true and the set of commands will run.
Can this be moved to a new 'else' block for the above 'if' block? Inside the 'if' you can set ovs_update_config to true. Avoids a call to ovs-vsctl.
No, it's part of jq syntax to return null.

Just to make sure I understand...you're proposing that for AIO-DX we're going to have mariadb-server use the 30-second timeout from openstack-helm-infra, but for the standard lab we want to change mariadb-server to use the same 5-second timeout that garbd is using?

Assuming that's the case, do we *want* to use the 5-second timeout?  Because the garbd chart is ours (openstack-armada-app/stx-openstack-helm/stx-openstack-helm/helm-charts/garbd), and we could just modify it to use the same timeout as mariadb-server--garbd is only used in the standard lab anyway so we only need to worry about one configuration.

Assuming we want to use the defaults for faster response time to failures, it also looks like we're going to change gmcast.peer_timeout back to the default as well...do we want to mention that in the git commit message?

For AIO-DX, it should doesn't matter, 5sec or 30sec timeout setting. As db-monitor will send pc.bootstrap to live mariadb-server if one controller reboot or shutdown. So this change affect AIO-DX or not, it has little impact.

For standard lab, we could update garbd helm chart. But I prefer to set with 5sec to improve response time and update commit message.

container-images/kolla/base/uid_gid_mana.message:
qq - why specify this as a lookup? given we call the script as an executable within all containers, could we just have this parse input and run the needed commands as a function?

Something like so
  bash /usr/local/bin/uid_gid_manage zaqar 42452 42452 /var/lib/zaqar kolla

In that way we define the interface as requiring 5 args, and remove ourselves from having to maintain this lookup.

yeah i thought about it and i also thought having this data in a single location would be easier to maintain until we get rid of it. It's also more easily discoverable, a bit like Kolla did where these info were into a variable.

nit: If we use a bash array to declare supported users we could drop the loop/logic to search for _USER_TO_CREATE?


  _USERS_TO_CREATE=$@

  declare -A _SUPPORTED_USERS
  _SUPPORTED_USERS['aodh']='aodh 42402 42402 /var/lib/aodh kolla'
  _SUPPORTED_USERS['barbican']='barbican 42403 42403 /var/lib/barbican kolla,nfast'

  _NAME=$(echo ${_SUPPORTED_USERS[$_USERS_TO_CREATE]} | awk '{ print $1 }')
  _UID=$(echo ${_SUPPORTED_USERS[$_USERS_TO_CREATE]} | awk '{ print $2 }')
  _GID=$(echo ${_SUPPORTED_USERS[$_USERS_TO_CREATE]} | awk '{ print $3 }')

  echo "User to create: ${_SUPPORTED_USERS[$_USERS_TO_CREATE]}"
  echo "NAME: $_NAME"
  echo "UID: $_UID"
  echo "GID: $_GID"
